GNS103.question: A library is defined as:
GNS103.explanation: Library is organized collection of information sources

GNS103.question: The first known library was in:
GNS103.explanation: Library of Ashurbanipal in Nineveh, Mesopotamia (7th century BCE)

GNS103.question: The Library of Alexandria was in:
GNS103.explanation: Library of Alexandria was in ancient Egypt

GNS103.question: A public library is funded by:
GNS103.explanation: Public libraries are government-funded for community use

GNS103.question: An academic library serves:
GNS103.explanation: Academic libraries support educational institutions

GNS103.question: School libraries are found in:
GNS103.explanation: School libraries serve K-12 students

GNS103.question: Special libraries serve:
GNS103.explanation: Special libraries serve corporations, hospitals, law firms

GNS103.question: National libraries preserve:
GNS103.explanation: National libraries collect and preserve a nation's publications

GNS103.question: An archive primarily contains:
GNS103.explanation: Archives preserve historical and organizational records

GNS103.question: A digital library provides:
GNS103.explanation: Digital libraries offer electronic/digitized materials

GNS103.question: Library organization involves:
GNS103.explanation: Organization makes resources findable and accessible

GNS103.question: Cataloging is the process of:
GNS103.explanation: Cataloging creates descriptions for library materials

GNS103.question: Classification arranges materials by:
GNS103.explanation: Classification groups similar subjects together

GNS103.question: Dewey Decimal Classification (DDC) uses:
GNS103.explanation: DDC uses numbers (000-999) for subjects

GNS103.question: Library of Congress Classification (LCC) uses:
GNS103.explanation: LCC uses letters for classes, numbers for subclasses

GNS103.question: The 800s in Dewey represent:
GNS103.explanation: 800-899 is Literature in DDC

GNS103.question: The 900s in Dewey represent:
GNS103.explanation: 900-999 is History and Geography

GNS103.question: A library catalog is:
options: List of all resources with locations
GNS103.explanation: Catalog shows what library has and where to find it

GNS103.question: OPAC stands for:
GNS103.explanation: OPAC is the online library catalog system

GNS103.question: Shelf arrangement follows:
GNS103.explanation: Books arranged by call number (classification + author)

GNS103.question: Reference resources include:
GNS103.explanation: Reference works provide quick facts and overviews

GNS103.question: An encyclopedia provides:
GNS103.explanation: Encyclopedias have comprehensive articles on various subjects

GNS103.question: A dictionary defines:
GNS103.explanation: Dictionaries explain word meanings, pronunciation, usage

GNS103.question: An almanac contains:
GNS103.explanation: Almanacs provide yearly updates on facts and figures

GNS103.question: An atlas is a collection of:
GNS103.explanation: Atlases contain maps and geographic information

GNS103.question: A directory lists:
options: People or organizations with contact info
GNS103.explanation: Directories provide names, addresses, contact details

GNS103.question: A biographical dictionary contains:
GNS103.explanation: Biographical sources provide life stories of individuals

GNS103.question: A yearbook covers:
GNS103.explanation: Yearbooks summarize events and developments of the year

GNS103.question: A handbook provides:
GNS103.explanation: Handbooks are concise reference for specific topics

GNS103.question: A manual gives:
options: Instructions on how to do something
GNS103.explanation: Manuals provide practical guidance and procedures

GNS103.question: A serial is a publication:
GNS103.explanation: Serials continue indefinitely (journals, magazines)

GNS103.question: A periodical is issued:
GNS103.explanation: Periodicals appear regularly (daily, weekly, monthly)

GNS103.question: A journal contains:
GNS103.explanation: Academic journals publish peer-reviewed research

GNS103.question: A magazine targets:
GNS103.explanation: Magazines are for general readership, popular topics

GNS103.question: A newsletter is usually:
GNS103.explanation: Newsletters brief members/organizations on current news

GNS103.question: ISSN stands for:
GNS103.explanation: ISSN uniquely identifies serial publications

GNS103.question: Electronic resources include:
GNS103.explanation: E-resources are digital information sources

GNS103.question: An e-book is:
GNS103.explanation: E-books are books in digital format

GNS103.question: An e-journal is:
GNS103.explanation: E-journals are digital versions of academic journals

GNS103.question: A database organizes:
options: Structured data for search and retrieval
GNS103.explanation: Databases allow systematic searching of information

GNS103.question: Academic writing is:
GNS103.explanation: Academic writing follows formal conventions and uses evidence

GNS103.question: A thesis statement:
GNS103.explanation: Thesis presents the central claim or argument

GNS103.question: Plagiarism is:
GNS103.explanation: Plagiarism is academic dishonesty - using others' work as own

GNS103.question: Citation gives:
GNS103.explanation: Citations acknowledge sources used in research

GNS103.question: APA style is used in:
GNS103.explanation: APA (American Psychological Association) used in social sciences

GNS103.question: MLA style is used in:
GNS103.explanation: MLA (Modern Language Association) used in humanities

GNS103.question: Chicago style is common in:
GNS103.explanation: Chicago Manual of Style used in history and publishing

GNS103.question: A bibliography lists:
GNS103.explanation: Bibliography includes all sources used for research

GNS103.question: References list includes:
GNS103.explanation: References only include works actually cited

GNS103.question: Peer review means:
GNS103.explanation: Peer review ensures quality through expert evaluation

GNS103.question: Information literacy is:
options: Ability to find, evaluate, use information
GNS103.explanation: Information literacy involves critical information skills

GNS103.question: Primary sources are:
GNS103.explanation: Primary sources are firsthand evidence (diaries, original research)

GNS103.question: Secondary sources:
GNS103.explanation: Secondary sources discuss primary sources

GNS103.question: A scholarly source is:
GNS103.explanation: Scholarly sources are academic and peer-reviewed

GNS103.question: Boolean operators include:
GNS103.explanation: Boolean operators connect search terms logically

GNS103.question: Using AND in search:
GNS103.explanation: AND requires all terms, narrowing results

GNS103.question: Using OR in search:
GNS103.explanation: OR includes any term, broadening results

GNS103.question: Using NOT in search:
GNS103.explanation: NOT excludes unwanted terms

GNS103.question: Truncation symbol (*) finds:
GNS103.explanation: Truncation finds different endings (comput* finds computer, computing)

GNS103.question: Phrase searching uses:
GNS103.explanation: Quotes find exact phrase ("climate change")

GNS103.question: Call number helps you:
GNS103.explanation: Call number is the book's address in library

GNS103.question: ISBN identifies:
GNS103.explanation: International Standard Book Number uniquely identifies books

GNS103.question: DOI (Digital Object Identifier) is:
GNS103.explanation: DOI provides permanent link to online content

GNS103.question: Interlibrary loan allows:
GNS103.explanation: ILL gets materials not in your library

GNS103.question: A thesaurus provides:
GNS103.explanation: Thesaurus lists words with similar/opposite meanings

GNS103.question: A gazetteer is a geographical:
GNS103.explanation: Gazetteer lists places with information

GNS103.question: Abstract of an article:
GNS103.explanation: Abstract summarizes the article's content

GNS103.question: Open access means:
GNS103.explanation: Open access is freely available online

GNS103.question: In-text citation appears:
GNS103.explanation: In-text citations mark sources within the text

GNS103.question: Footnote appears at:
GNS103.explanation: Footnotes are at page bottom, endnotes at chapter/book end

GNS103.question: A literature review:
GNS103.explanation: Literature review surveys scholarly sources on a topic

GNS103.question: A research question:
GNS103.explanation: Research question focuses the study

GNS103.question: Hypothesis is:
GNS103.explanation: Hypothesis is an educated guess to test

GNS103.question: Methodology describes:
GNS103.explanation: Methodology explains research methods used

GNS103.question: Quantitative research uses:
GNS103.explanation: Quantitative research deals with numbers and measurements

GNS103.question: Qualitative research uses:
GNS103.explanation: Qualitative research explores meanings and experiences

GNS103.question: A case study examines:
GNS103.explanation: Case study deeply investigates one person/group/event

GNS103.question: Survey research uses:
GNS103.explanation: Surveys collect data through questions

GNS103.question: Sampling in research:
GNS103.explanation: Sampling selects subset to represent whole

GNS103.question: Random sample means:
GNS103.explanation: Random sampling gives everyone equal opportunity

GNS103.question: Copyright protects:
GNS103.explanation: Copyright covers expression, not ideas

GNS103.question: Fair use allows:
GNS103.explanation: Fair use permits limited use without permission

GNS103.question: Public domain means:
GNS103.explanation: Public domain works are not copyrighted

GNS103.question: Creative Commons licenses:
GNS103.explanation: Creative Commons allows flexible sharing

GNS103.question: Censorship in libraries:
GNS103.explanation: Censorship removes or restricts access to materials

GNS103.question: Intellectual freedom means:
options: Freedom to read and access information
GNS103.explanation: Intellectual freedom supports free access to ideas

GNS103.question: A library mission statement:
GNS103.explanation: Mission states library's reason for existence

GNS103.question: Collection development is:
GNS103.explanation: Collection development builds library collections

GNS103.question: Weeding removes:
GNS103.explanation: Weeding keeps collection current and useful

GNS103.question: Preservation in libraries:
GNS103.explanation: Preservation extends life of library materials

GNS103.question: A library consortium is:
GNS103.explanation: Consortia share resources and collaborate

GNS103.question: Reference interview is:
GNS103.explanation: Reference interview clarifies what user really needs

GNS103.question: Ready reference questions are:
GNS103.explanation: Ready reference finds brief, specific facts

GNS103.question: Subject headings describe:
GNS103.explanation: Subject headings indicate content topics

GNS103.question: LCSH stands for:
GNS103.explanation: LCSH is standard subject vocabulary

GNS103.question: MARC records are used for:
GNS103.explanation: MARC is format for bibliographic data

GNS103.question: RFID in libraries helps with:
GNS103.explanation: RFID tags help with inventory and security

GNS103.question: A library's annual report:
GNS103.explanation: Annual report summarizes library's year

GNS103.question: Information ethics deals with:
GNS103.explanation: Information ethics covers privacy, access, intellectual property

GNS103.question: The right to information is:
GNS103.explanation: Access to information is recognized as human right
